title: The Sunday Read: Getting Out
description: After serving time for a crime he committed at 16, one man discovered how hard it is for a felon to get a second chance in America.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 14, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, June 14, 2020.
content: An article on Page 8 about Bob Dylan misspelled a name in a lyric in “Key West (Philosopher’s Pirate).” It is “Ginsberg, Corso and Kerouac,” not “Ginsburg, Corso and Kerouac.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Find comfort in lamb biryani, a lentil-orzo stew, or a feta-brined roast chicken.
content: Good morning. Joy is in short supply these days, and patience, too. Nerves are tingling. I haven’t shaken a hand or hugged someone outside my family in more than three months. Cooking’s supposed to be a solace — I say that every day — but I acknowledge that some days it doesn’t seem possible. I do it anyway (gotta eat). I do it anyway (it’s a practice, same as singing scales, same as draining free throws). I do it anyway (I believe).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful
title: Thousands March for Black Transgender Lives
description: Thousands of demonstrators gathered around the Brooklyn Museum to bring attention to high rates of police violence against black transgender women.
content: Thousands of demonstrators gathered around the Brooklyn Museum to bring attention to high rates of police violence against black transgender women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: The Long Battle Over ‘Gone With the Wind’
description: The 1939 blockbuster once symbolized the ultimate in mass entertainment. But African-Americans have protested against it from the start, even if white America didn’t want to hear it.
content: When HBO Max announced Tuesday that it was temporarily removing “Gone With the Wind” from its streaming service, it seemed as if another Confederate monument was coming down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Chris Wallace, Insider and Outlier at Fox News
description: The “Fox News Sunday” anchor opens up about his childhood, career and what he makes of his pro-Trump colleagues.
content: Chris Wallace is a registered Democrat who hosts “Fox News Sunday,” a child of two Jews who keeps a rosary by his bedside, a Washington wonk who has vacationed in Italy with George Clooney.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mercedes Lilienthal
title: Life on the Road in Pandemic America
description: Truck stops instead of motels, hand sanitizer instead of candy and 16 tanks of fuel to buy an oddball van and drive it home.
content: What happens when a dream car is for sale in Florida, you live in Oregon and a pandemic is gripping the country?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: A Stimulus Backlash Delivers a Global Warning: Value Female Workers
description: Australia is pouring millions into the male-dominated construction industry while ending free child care. Critics say that is illogical and reflects sexist biases.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — Shelley Duggan became an essential worker when Australia declared that her job at a suburban child care center must be preserved so that doctors and nurses would have a place to send their children during the coronavirus outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: An Insatiable Rage
description: It is an everyday struggle to neither fall into despair nor explode in anger.
content: In the wake of the killing of George Floyd and the massive wave of protests that have swept the country and the world, New York State on Friday passed a package of policing reforms, banning chokeholds and opening police disciplinary records, among other things.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Coronavirus Flare-Up, U.S. Police, Facebook: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Chris Wallace, Insider and Outlier at Fox News
description: The “Fox News Sunday” anchor opens up about his childhood, career and what he makes of his pro-Trump colleagues.
content: Chris Wallace is a registered Democrat who hosts “Fox News Sunday,” a child of two Jews who keeps a rosary by his bedside, a Washington wonk who has vacationed in Italy with George Clooney.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: A Stimulus Backlash Delivers a Global Warning: Value Female Workers
description: Australia is pouring millions into the male-dominated construction industry while ending free child care. Critics say that is illogical and reflects sexist biases.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — Shelley Duggan became an essential worker when Australia declared that her job at a suburban child care center must be preserved so that doctors and nurses would have a place to send their children during the coronavirus outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: An Insatiable Rage
description: It is an everyday struggle to neither fall into despair nor explode in anger.
content: In the wake of the killing of George Floyd and the massive wave of protests that have swept the country and the world, New York State on Friday passed a package of policing reforms, banning chokeholds and opening police disciplinary records, among other things.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Robbins
title: A Canal That Opened the Montana Prairie May Soon Dry Up
description: An early 20th-century federal water project irrigated the prairie to create farms and towns in eastern Montana. But it needs a $200 million overhaul.
content: CUT BANK, Mont. — A century ago, one of the first of the ambitious federal water projects that helped build the West was constructed to carry water from the mountains of Glacier National Park hundreds of miles east, irrigating an area twice the size of Maryland.
source.name: The New York Times

title: As Social Distancing Wanes, Cuomo Warns of Another Lockdown
description: Sports bettors are shifting to stocks. Brazil’s daily death toll is now the highest globally, and Peru is one of the world’s hot spots.
content: With sunny and warm weekend weather in New York City and its suburbs, social media feeds were filled with videos and reports of residents violating social distancing rules, including Friday night in Manhattan’s East Village, a bar-and-restaurant friendly neighborhood. Outdoor drinkers, many without masks, also congregated on street corners in Hell’s Kitchen on Saturday, where gay pride celebrations were underway.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘One Friday Night, I Pulled Into the Tollbooth at the Henry Hudson Bridge’
description: A tip on the way home, buying croissants at Zabar’s and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: The Second Wave Is Coming
description: How bad will it be?
content: After another week of widespread protests and relaxed lockdown rules, coronavirus cases are spiking in over a dozen states. What does that mean for the economy? Catch up on the big stories in business and tech for the week ahead, and stay safe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Make Better
description: Sure, it’s Monday, but here’s an Olivia Mitra Framke puzzle.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Today’s grid marks Olivia Mitra Framke’s Monday debut and her fifth puzzle with us over all. If you’re on a long puzzle streak, you’ve probably solved her excellent Sunday constructions. (Her first Times puzzle was a Sunday that paid homage to 68A, you might remember.) If you’re still working on Mondays, you can try one of her Tuesday puzzles once you’re done here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Seligson
title: Author Frances Cha on Achieving the Feminine Ideal
description: The author of “If I Had Your Face,” discusses her debut novel — a story of four women pursuing dreams and ambitions in fiercely competitive Seoul.
content: — Frances Cha, author of “If I Had Your Face”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman and Mitch Smith
title: Coronavirus Cases Spike Across Sun Belt as Economy Lurches into Motion
description: Arizona, Texas and Florida are reporting their highest case numbers yet. As of Saturday, coronavirus cases were climbing in 22 states amid reopenings.
content: CHICAGO — The warning has echoed ominously for weeks from epidemiologists, small-town mayors and county health officials: Once states begin to reopen, a surge in coronavirus cases will follow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: The Artist’s Caretaker: Once He Controlled Everything. No More.
description: When Robert Indiana died, the man who had directed his affairs was supposed to help run the artist’s foundation and its new museum. Those plans have changed.
content: One person was conspicuously absent from an event at the Farnsworth Museum in Rockland, Maine, last year, a gathering as close to a memorial for Robert Indiana as has been held since his death two years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Senior
title: More People Will Be Fired in the Pandemic. Let’s Talk About It.
description: For starters, don’t do it on Zoom. And consider not doing it at all.
content: Years ago, I stumbled across some startling research by economists in England and Australia: It takes longer to adapt to the pain of unemployment than to losing a loved one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael E. O'Hanlon
title: Joe Biden Needs to Learn an Urgent Lesson From the 2004 Election
description: Bush survived the Iraq war. Trump has mishandled the coronavirus and the protests, but Americans care more about plans going forward.
content: We know that a bad economy tends to hurt the electoral prospects of incumbent presidential candidates. But what about a crisis of national security or American safety? Although the coronavirus pandemic is unprecedented in most ways, as is the Trump presidency itself, there may be historical lessons from other situations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal, Fatima Faizi, Najim Rahim and Taimoor Shah
title: Desperate for Any Coronavirus Care, Afghans Flock to Herbalist’s ‘Vaccine’
description: Afghanistan’s health system, largely dependent on foreign aid, has been overwhelmed, and official numbers are seen as an indication of a widening catastrophe.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Every day, thousands of people swarmed Hakeem Alokozai’s herbal clinic in Kabul seeking their three drops of his Covid-19 “vaccine.” Some carried IV drips, others oxygen cylinders. Some were brought in ambulances, others in the back of Toyota station wagons. They were laborers, officers of the security forces and even lawmakers in the country’s Parliament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein
title: She Survived the Coronavirus. Then She Got a $400,000 Medical Bill.
description: Patients who were treated for the virus are largely supposed to be exempt from receiving large bills.
content: Janet Mendez started receiving bills soon after returning in April to her mother’s home from Mount Sinai Morningside hospital, where she nearly died of Covid-19. First, there was one for $31,165. Unable to work and finding it difficult to walk, Ms. Mendez decided to put the bill out of her mind and focus on her recovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Weininger
title: My Favorite String Quartet
description: Fifty years ago, the Alban Berg Quartet was founded. A huge box set, comforting yet daring, is an immersive celebration.
content: Half a century ago, a string quartet formed in Vienna. This might not seem like an especially noteworthy event, given that city’s towering importance in the history of music — and chamber music, in particular. Surely quartets have always been a dime a dozen there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Racial Justice Groups Flooded With Millions in Donations in Wake of Floyd Death
description: Progressive and racial justice groups have seen a cascade of donations since George Floyd’s death and the ensuing protests. Bail funds alone have received $90 million.
content: The killing of George Floyd and the ensuing nationwide wave of protests are generating a record-setting flood of donations to racial justice groups, bail funds and black-led advocacy organizations across America, remaking the financial landscape of black political activism in a matter of weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Biden Can Fight Racism
description: A reader suggests “a cabinet-level position devoted to eradicating racism.” Also: The Republican vote this fall; hospital finances in the pandemic.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Monika Pronczuk
title: Coronavirus Created an Obstacle Course for Safe Abortions
description: But during the pandemic, a few countries liberalized their requirements, allowing at-home medical terminations.
content: BRUSSELS — When a 19-year-old woman from southern Poland decided to end her pregnancy at 18 weeks, she knew the only way to get an abortion was to rush to a neighboring European country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Arora
title: Sushant Singh Rajput, Bollywood Star, Dies at 34
description: Mr. Rajput, best known for his roles in the films “Kai Po Che” and “M.S. Dhoni: The Untold Story,” got his start on television in 2008.
content: Sushant Singh Rajput, a prominent actor in Indian films and television programs, was found dead in his home in Mumbai on Sunday. He was 34.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: Families Challenge Suicide in Deaths of Black Men Found Hanging From Trees
description: The bodies of Robert Fuller and Malcolm Harsch were found in California, 10 days and 50 miles apart. Their families are demanding deeper investigations.
content: The families of two black men who were found hanged from trees in Southern California are asking the authorities to further investigate their deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Details of Shooting in Atlanta Fuel Debate on Police Use of Force
description: After another black man is shot and killed by police officers, Atlanta erupts in outrage, and discussion swirls around proposals to radically overhaul law enforcement around the country.
content: This briefing has ended. Follow our continuing coverage of Atlanta, Black Lives Matter and police protests here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Mele and Johnny Diaz
title: Tasers: Are These Police Tools Effective and Are They Dangerous?
description: The fatal police shooting of Rayshard Brooks in Atlanta has put a spotlight on a number of officer tactics, including the use of Tasers.
content: The fatal police shooting of Rayshard Brooks, a black man who was found asleep in a car in a drive-through at a Wendy’s on Friday night in Atlanta, has reignited the debate over Tasers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malachy Browne, Christina Kelso and Barbara Marcolini
title: How Rayshard Brooks Was Fatally Shot by the Atlanta Police
description: One officer has been fired and another placed on administrative duty. A Times video analysis shows the sequence of events leading to the fatal shooting.
content: The Atlanta Police Department said early Sunday that an officer had been fired over the fatal shooting of Rayshard Brooks, 27, at a Wendy’s restaurant. The officer, Garrett Rolfe, who had worked with the department since 2013, fired his handgun three times while he was chasing Mr. Brooks, who the authorities said had seized a Taser from an officer and fired it as he ran. Another officer on the scene, Devin Brosnan, who has been with the department for less than two years, was placed on administrative duty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips
title: Trading Sportsbooks for Brokerages, Bored Bettors Wager on Stocks
description: When Russian table tennis or Korean baseball won’t scratch the itch, some are trying their hand at trading equities. It’s enough to move the market, analysts say.
content: When he wasn’t coaching sports, he was playing them or watching them. And if he was watching — well, a little skin in the game always made it more interesting for Steven Young, a teacher outside Philadelphia. Just small-dollar bets, mixed in with shuffling the rosters of his fantasy teams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman and Ruth Maclean
title: Slowing the Coronavirus Is Speeding the Spread of Other Diseases
description: Many mass immunization efforts worldwide were halted this spring to prevent spread of the virus at crowded inoculation sites. The consequences have been alarming.
content: As poor countries around the world struggle to beat back the coronavirus, they are unintentionally contributing to fresh explosions of illness and death from other diseases — ones that are readily prevented by vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Still Raising a Fist, 52 Years Later
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 14, 2020.
content: “All I did was stand there with a fist in the air. It was a cry for freedom.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: Michelle Wikum, Walker Williams
description: The couple met through Tinder in 2018.
content: Michelle Joy Wikum and Walker Samuel Williams were married June 13 at the home of the bride’s parents in Santa Ana, Calif. The Rev. Dr. Dena L. Williams, a Lutheran minister and the groom’s mother, officiated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Messman
title: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘30 for 30’ and ‘Marcella’
description: Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa revisit the home run record chase of 1998, and the dark detective drama returns to Netflix.
content: 30 FOR 30: LONG GONE SUMMER 9 p.m. on ESPN. During the summer of 1998, many sports fans seemed to be captivated by one single story — the chase between the St. Louis Cardinals’ Mark McGwire and the Chicago Cubs’ Sammy Sosa to beat Roger Maris’s record of 61 home runs in a single season. In this documentary, Sosa and McGwire take viewers back to the high-drama slugfest. The film also explores how the revelations of steroid use in the league would later call the accomplishments of the sport — and that season — into question.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: A New Book Brings Melania Trump Into (Slightly) Better Focus
description: “The Art of Her Deal,” by the Washington Post reporter Mary Jordan, is about the life and the influence of the unconventional first lady.
content: To the Secret Service, he is “Mogul” and she is “Muse.” Donald J. Trump and Melania Knauss met in Manhattan in 1998 and married seven years later. He was a real estate guy and she had curb appeal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: How the Stoop and the Sidewalk Helped New Yorkers Stay Sane
description: A look back at maybe the one good thing to come out of lockdown: getting to know your neighbors.
content: Impromptu concerts from the fire escape. Food relief efforts staged on the sidewalk in front of a church. Friends spread out on the stoop and drinking tallboys. As the city reopens, New Yorkers emerging from quarantine might feel a bit nostalgic for the socially distant bonds they formed outside their homes. From the first days of the lockdown in April, through the advent of legal drinking in front of restaurants, to protests in the streets for racial justice, The Times collected stories of how neighbors across the five boroughs handled the shutdown and, at times, came together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: A Pop-Culture Glossary for ‘Da 5 Bloods’
description: Spike Lee’s movie is filled with references to movies and Vietnam-era events. We explain who’s who and what’s what.
content: Through their blistering engagement with history, pop culture and headlines, Spike Lee’s movies always brim with references, and “Da 5 Bloods,” his new feature on Netflix, is no exception. The drama follows four Vietnam veterans, “the Bloods” — Paul (Delroy Lindo), Otis (Clarke Peters), Eddie (Norm Lewis) and Melvin (Isiah Whitlock Jr.) — who return to the country with a dual purpose: to recover the remains of their fallen comrade and to retrieve the gold they buried. A critique of U.S. exploitation of African-Americans in war and in general, “Da 5 Bloods” is also an adventure film and a caper movie, filled with callbacks to Lee’s other works. Below is a guide to some of its many allusions and shout-outs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: Upright Citizens Brigade to Overhaul Its Leadership
description: Amy Poehler other founders of this struggling bicoastal comedy incubator say they want to hand over its theaters to a diverse board that would address issues of systemic racism and inequality.
content: The Upright Citizens Brigade comedy organization, which has been financially troubled in recent years, has announced an effort to diversify its ranks and remake itself, at least in part, as a nonprofit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Robert Gates Calls to Replace Base Names From ‘Dark Side of Our History’
description: The former defense secretary became the most senior previous military leader in recent days to endorse renaming 10 Army installations that bear the names of Confederate generals.
content: Former Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates joined the call on Sunday to rename Army bases named after Confederate generals despite President Trump’s opposition, saying that it was time to rid the American military of symbols that represent “the dark side of our history.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: Trump Rally Is the ‘Perfect Storm Setup,’ for Viral Spread, Disease Expert Says
description: Campaign rallies like those planned by Trump and other social gatherings could spread infections this summer. People should adhere to wearing masks and continue social distancing, public health researchers say.
content: The coronavirus won’t be loosening its grip on the United States any time soon, leading infectious disease experts said on Sunday. They are also uncertain how the viral spread will be affected by the patchwork of states reopening businesses and by large events like protests and President Trump’s upcoming campaign rallies.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Passengers Still Jittery About Flying
description: Readers describe travel experiences on planes and in airports that left them uneasy and call for more rigorous safety measures.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: My Front-Row View of the Cuomo Briefings
description: I’ve covered Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo for seven years, and thought I understood him well. Then the virus came, and his news conferences started.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Elijah Walker
title: Black Lives Matter, Reopening, Pride Month: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jen A. Miller
title: A Conversation With the Ultrarunner Yassine Diboun
description: “I can’t be silent anymore.”
content: Welcome to the Running newsletter! Every Saturday morning, we email runners with news, advice and some motivation to help you get up and running. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven McDonald
title: As a Black Doctor, Should I Choose My Skin Color or My Health?
description: I understand that the protests are necessary medicine for both the pandemic and our country’s racism.
content: As a black emergency medicine physician, concern about the spread of Covid-19 at protests in the wake of the murder of George Floyd is not top of my mind. And yet many continue to seize on this concern. The risk of spread of Covid-19 is clearly elevated at demonstrations: People are yelling, stirring up respiratory droplets and projecting them into the air; people are marching long distances, exerting themselves and taking gulps of air in the process; people are standing and kneeling much less than six feet from one another; and mask use is, over all, abundant but admittedly inconsistent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yousur Al-Hlou and Ora DeKornfeld
title: Coronavirus ‘Ripped A Hole’ In N.Y.C.’s Black Community. This Funeral Director Knows.
description: In New York City, Covid-19 is disproportionately killing black and Latino residents. As the city reopens, a longtime funeral director in Harlem says, “It’s going to take a long time for people to heal.”
content: In New York City, Covid-19 is disproportionately killing black and Latino residents. As the city reopens, a longtime funeral director in Harlem says, “It’s going to take a long time for people to heal.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Erdbrink and Christina Anderson
title: Fears for Volvo Expose Sour Turn in Sweden’s Ties With China
description: When a Chinese manufacturer swept in to save the Swedish car marque, it was warmly welcomed. A decade later, plans for a fuller merger are being debated in a frostier atmosphere.
content: GOTHENBURG, Sweden — The 2009 meeting in Shanghai between the Swedish union leader and the “Chinese Henry Ford” started in a minibus ride and ended in one of the financial capital’s most opulent hotels. There, the men struck an unlikely alliance to save the struggling Swedish carmaker Volvo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Covid-19 Changed How We Vote. It Could Also Change Who Votes.
description: In presidential election years, state driver licensing offices and registration drives generate a torrent of new voters. The pandemic has cut that to a trickle.
content: WASHINGTON — In a normal election year, volunteers from the Columbus, Ohio, chapter of the League of Women Voters would have spent last weekend at the Columbus Arts Fair, pens and clipboards in hand, looking to sign up new voters among the festival’s 400,000 or so attendees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: In an English City, an Early Benefactor Is Now ‘a Toxic Brand’
description: Bristol was built with money from the slave trader Edward Colston. Tearing down his statue has reopened a painful reckoning with the city’s racist past.
content: BRISTOL, England — Standing beneath an empty stone plinth, from which the statue of the 17th-century slave trader Edward Colston was toppled last week, Richard Saunders showed his son photos of three black Americans who had been killed by the police an ocean away and 200 years after the end of Bristol’s slave trade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa
title: The Woman Who Took Down a Confederate Flag on What Came Next
description: Bree Newsome Bass was arrested after climbing a flagpole at the South Carolina State Capitol. Now, she sees more people moved to act for similar reasons.
content: She knew she would be arrested, but that was the least of her concerns. She had to make it to the top of the flagpole first.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Trump’s Halting Walk Down Ramp Raises New Health Questions
description: The president also appeared to have trouble raising a glass of water to his mouth during a speech at West Point a day before he turned 74, the oldest a president has been in his first term.
content: President Trump faced new questions about his health on Sunday, after videos emerged of him gingerly walking down a ramp at the U.S. Military Academy at West Point and having trouble bringing a glass of water to his mouth during a speech there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: G.O.P. Congressman Is Ousted From Right After Officiating at Same-Sex Wedding
description: Representative Denver Riggleman of Virginia, who was endorsed by President Trump, lost his re-election bid in an unusual drive-through convention to a self-described “biblical conservative.”
content: WASHINGTON — Representative Denver Riggleman, a freshman Republican from Virginia, lost a bitterly contested primary race decided in an unusual drive-through state convention, weighed down by outrage among party activists that he officiated at a same-sex wedding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Pawel
title: The Pandemic and Protests Have Exposed the Truth About California
description: The Golden State is less exceptional and more like the rest of America than many would prefer to believe.
content: PASADENA — California, the novelist Wallace Stegner wrote, is like the rest of America, only more so. That truism has played out in recent days in scenes of triumph, anguish and incongruity, a mirror of the country seen through a distinctly California lens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola, Kevin Draper and Eros Hoagland
title: We Went Inside a Sports ‘Bubble.’ Here’s What We Saw.
description: Boxers wearing surgical booties. Wristbands with bar codes. Meals served behind plexiglass. Our journalists took a look behind the scenes of boxing’s comeback in Las Vegas.
content: LAS VEGAS — Robeisy Ramirez had no idea that his fourth professional bout as a featherweight boxer would come in the middle of a pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: How 2 Lives Collided in Central Park, Rattling the Nation
description: The inside story of the black birder and the white woman who called the police on him. Their encounter stirred wrenching conversations about racism and white privilege.
content: Christian Cooper began his Memorial Day like most of his May mornings, searching for Blackburnian warblers, scarlet tanagers and other songbirds that wing their way into Central Park.
source.name: The New York Times
